user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_parse_arguments_:
```c
enum MHD_Result
MHD_parse_arguments_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                      enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                      char *args,
                      MHD_ArgumentIterator_ cb,
                      void *cls)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;
  char *equals;
  char *amper;

  while ( (NULL != args) &&
          ('\0' != args[0]) )
  {
    size_t key_len;
    size_t value_len;
    equals = strchr (args, '=');
    amper = strchr (args, '&');
    if (NULL == amper)
    {
      /* last argument */
      if (NULL == equals)
      {
        /* last argument, without '=' */
        MHD_unescape_plus (args);
        key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                             connection,
                                             args);
        if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                          args,
                          key_len,
                          NULL,
                          0,
                          kind))
          return MHD_NO;
        break;
      }
      /* got 'foo=bar' */
      equals[0] = '\0';
      equals++;
      MHD_unescape_plus (args);
      key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           args);
      MHD_unescape_plus (equals);
      value_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                             connection,
                                             equals);
      if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                        args,
                        key_len,
                        equals,
                        value_len,
                        kind))
        return MHD_NO;
      break;
    }
    /* amper is non-NULL here */
    amper[0] = '\0';
    amper++;
    if ( (NULL == equals) ||
         (equals >= amper) )
    {
      /* got 'foo&bar' or 'foo&bar=val', add key 'foo' with NULL for value */
      MHD_unescape_plus (args);
      key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           args);
      if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                        args,
                        key_len,
                        NULL,
                        0,
                        kind))
        return MHD_NO;
      /* continue with 'bar' */
      args = amper;
      continue;
    }
    /* equals and amper are non-NULL here, and equals < amper,
 so we got regular 'foo=value&bar...'-kind of argument */
    equals[0] = '\0';
    equals++;
    MHD_unescape_plus (args);
    key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                         connection,
                                         args);
    MHD_unescape_plus (equals);
    value_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           equals);
    if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                      args,
                      key_len,
                      equals,
                      value_len,
                      kind))
      return MHD_NO;
    args = amper;
  }
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_parse_arguments_:
void
MHD_unescape_plus (char *arg)
{
  char *p;

  for (p = strchr (arg, '+'); NULL != p; p = strchr (p + 1, '+'))
    *p = ' ';
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only assignments that reassign a function parameter itself are relevant to MISRA C:2023 Rule 17.8. In this function the only parameter that is reassigned is 'args' (two occurrences listed above). Other potentially-modifying operations in the code modify either: (a) the objects pointed to by pointer parameters (for example equals[0] = '\0', amper[0] = '\0', MHD_unescape_plus(...) which writes characters) — these are allowed by the rule — or (b) local pointer variables (equals, amper, p, daemon), which may be modified freely. The other parameters (connection, kind, cb, cls) are not reassigned. Therefore no additional fragments need investigation under Rule 17.8.
